title: Multiple repeated actions isn't helpful
body: Testing #264266 As the agent was working it updated the README file multiple times, but did not provide any more info: The result feels redundant & takes up valuable vertical space - maybe there is a way to consolidate these similar actions

title: No idea what repo coding agent was working on
body:
Testing #264266

I have multiple repos open in my workspace. When I asked the agent to update the readme with emojis I had no idea which repo it was working in - I think it chose the first repo open with coding agent enabled, which was vscode, but there was no UI to confirm this choice.

title: SCM Graph - icons are not shown in the hover in Insiders
body:
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes - VS Code Version: ``` Version: 1.104.0-insider (user setup) Commit: 966ec1415440da5f1ef53acbd97ba2113add8853 Date: 2025-09-02T05:05:45.743Z Electron: 37.3.1 ElectronBuildId: 12259562 Chromium: 138.0.7204.235 Node.js: 22.18.0 V8: 13.8.258.31-electron.0 OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 ``` - OS Version: Windows 11 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open Source Control 2. Open Graph 3. Hover on any entry In hover menu icons about copy commit ID and open link on GitHub are not displayed. Marked on the screenshot below.
Screenshot left Insiders, right stable build
I'm not sure if it's a bug or changed intentionally, but without copy icon it's not obvious what clicking on ID do.
One more thing unrelated to this issue is that it would be nice to have an indicator showing that something was copied. I don't mean `Graph` only, but in general. For example, in Chat if `Copy` icon is clicked then there is no information that something was copied. Something like it's done on GitHub website when "Copy" button is clicked.
Screenshot
But I guess I should open a new issue (tried to find similar but could not).

title: Changing mode while tool set picker is open will apply tools to new mode
body:
Testing #264401

1. make sure you have 2 different custom modes
2. select one of the modes
3. open tool picker and make changes, but do not press ok or close the picker
4. in the chat change the selected mode
5. close the picker
6. 🐍 The tools are now applied to the new mode and not to the mode which was selected when opening the picker

Potential fix: If the picker is open and the mode changes, close the picker without applying the changes

title: Response API - ask mode observation

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

labels.name: candidate
labels.description: Issue identified as probable candidate for fixing in the next release

body:
Testing #263353

Toggled the setting and used the Copilot Chat Debug view to confirm that the setting took effect. I have switched to `ask` mode and sent multiple messages and the response format seemed very strange to me. They all started with stating the "Task", a "Plan" and sometimes a "Checklist".  Maybe this is expected for the response API and if we maybe we should do some processing before rendering it. 

Here are some examples:

```txt
Is there a way to do variable padding but the padding would always be an even number using CSS variables that use em?
========
Task: Explain how `em` works when used on `padding`, with examples and gotchas.

Plan:
- Define what `1em` resolves to for padding.
- Contrast with `font-size` and `rem`.
- Show quick examples, including variables.
- Call out key gotchas.

Answer continued...
```

```txt
Is there a way to do variable padding but the padding would always be an even number using CSS variables that use em?
========
Task: Ensure padding set via CSS variables is always an even number of em.

Plan:
- Show a compatibility-safe pattern (no special math functions).
- Add a “round to even” pattern using modern CSS math with an @supports gate.
- Include per‑axis example and key notes.

Checklist:
- Variable-driven padding in em.
- Always even value (2, 4, 6, … em).
- Works with unitless or length variables.
- Provide a safe fallback.

Answer continued...
```

```txt
How would you use em to implement variable padding?
========
Task: Show practical ways to make padding variable using em.

Plan:
- Use a unitless scale custom property and multiply by 1em.
- Provide per-axis and token-based variants.
- Add optional bounds and typed custom properties.
- Call out key gotchas.

Checklist:
- Define unitless variables for scale.
- Apply with `calc(var(--x) * 1em)` and sensible fallbacks.
- Support per-axis/per-side overrides.
- Optional: tokens, `clamp()`, `@property` typing.
- Note em behavior and var+unit pitfall.

Answer continued...
```

title: feat(ts-codeLens): show "implementations" CodeLens for overridden methods #263749
body:
Summary
This PR adds support for showing "implementations" CodeLens on TypeScript methods that are overridden in derived classes.

Changes
Extended TypeScriptImplementationsCodeLensProvider to surface implementations for:
Class methods (not just interfaces or abstract methods)
Overridden methods in derived classes
Updated extractSymbol logic to correctly identify these symbols
Added smoke test: implementationsCodeLens.test.ts to validate behavior
Why
Resolves https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/198387.

Developers can now see "1 implementation" / "n implementations" CodeLens above methods that are overridden, and navigate directly to their derived class implementations.
This aligns CodeLens behavior with the “Find All Implementations” command.

Verification
Open an abstract/base class with a method that is overridden in derived classes.
Confirm that the "implementations" CodeLens appears above the method.
Clicking it navigates to the derived class overrides.
Testing
Local build & compile successful
Hygiene checks passed
Smoke test added & executed
Integration tests run successfully (scripts/test-integration.bat)
Notes
This improvement makes CodeLens more consistent and increases productivity when working with object-oriented TypeScript codebases.

Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/198387

title: Shell Script Syntax Highlighting Breaks After Using Shift Operator (<<)

labels.name: grammar
labels.description: Syntax highlighting grammar

labels.name: upstream-issue-linked
labels.description: This is an upstream issue that has been reported upstream

body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No Version: 1.103.1 (user setup) Commit: 360a4e4fd251bfce169a4ddf857c7d25d1ad40da Date: 2025-08-12T16:25:40.542Z Electron: 37.2.3 ElectronBuildId: 12035395 Chromium: 138.0.7204.100 Node.js: 22.17.0 V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0 OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 During Shell script development, we've identified a syntax highlighting issue. When the shift operator (<<) is used in the code, it causes incorrect syntax highlighting for the subsequent code. This issue is specific to the syntax highlighter used in our environment. Steps to Reproduce: 1. Write or open a Shell script file. 2. Include a line that uses the << operator (e.g., for a here-document). 3. Observe the syntax highlighting for the code following this operator. Example Code Snippet `check_bit(){     local result=$(devmem $1)     local result_num="$2"     local mask_bit0=1     local mask_bit4=(( 1 << 3))     local mask_bit4=(( 1 << 4 ))     if ((result & mask_bit0) && (result & mask_bit4)); then         echo "result $result_num verify successed: $result"     else         echo "result $result_num verify failed: $result"     fi }` The issue arises after `local mask_bit4 = ((1 << 3))`, causing syntax highlighting anomalies in that line and subsequent code.

title: GitHub Copilot: Inconsistent performance and unresponsiveness requiring IDE restart.
body:
Type: Bug Issue Description: Following recent updates, GitHub Copilot's performance has become highly inconsistent. The extension alternates between periods of correct functionality and prolonged states of unresponsiveness where it fails to provide any suggestions. This instability significantly disrupts the development workflow. The only reliable workaround to restore functionality is to completely restart the Visual Studio Code instance. Steps to Reproduce: The issue is intermittent and difficult to reproduce reliably with specific steps. However, it generally occurs during a normal coding session: Work on a project for an extended period. Notice that Copilot suggestions, initially fluid, start to lag or cease to appear altogether. The unresponsiveness persists across different files and projects within the same session. title: Add strategic emojis to README for enhanced readability and engagement
body:
This PR adds carefully selected emojis to the VS Code README to improve visual hierarchy, enhance readability, and make the documentation more engaging while maintaining professionalism.

## Changes Made

The emojis have been strategically placed in the following areas:

**Section Headers:**
- Main title: Added 💻 to represent code/development
- Contributing section: Added 🤝 to represent collaboration
- Feedback section: Added 💬 to represent communication
- Bundled Extensions: Added 🧩 to represent puzzle pieces/modularity
- Development Container: Added 🐳 to represent Docker containers

**Action Items:**
- Bug reporting: 🐛 for bug submissions
- Code review: 📝 for reviewing changes
- Documentation: 📚 for documentation contributions
- Building: 🏗️ for build instructions
- Development workflow: 🔧 for development tools
- Guidelines: 📋 for coding standards
- Pull requests: 🔄 for submission process
- Issue discovery: 🔍 for finding work
- Translations: 🌍 for internationalization
- Questions: ❓ for Stack Overflow
- Feature requests: ✨ for new features
- Upvoting: 👍 for popular requests
- Community: 💭 for discussions
- Social media: 🐦 for Twitter

**Downloads and Links:**
- Download link: 💾 for software downloads
- Insiders build: 🚀 for cutting-edge releases

## Design Principles

The emoji selection follows these principles:
- **Professional**: All emojis are appropriate for a Microsoft open-source project
- **Intuitive**: Each emoji clearly represents its associated action or concept
- **Consistent**: Similar actions use similar emoji styles
- **Minimal**: Only added where they enhance understanding, not overwhelming the content
- **Accessible**: Universal symbols that work across cultures and platforms

The changes improve the README's scannability and help users quickly identify different types of contributions and resources available in the VS Code ecosystem.

title: Add global editor.readOnly setting to make all editors read-only
body:
This PR implements a new global `editor.readOnly` setting that allows users to make all editors read-only across VS Code.

## Problem

VS Code currently supports per-file readonly functionality through:
- File system permissions 
- Session-specific readonly toggles
- Glob pattern configurations (`files.readonlyInclude`/`files.readonlyExclude`)

However, there was no way for users to globally make ALL editors read-only, which is useful for scenarios like:
- Code review sessions where editing should be prevented
- Read-only exploration of unfamiliar codebases
- Presentation or demonstration modes
- Safety measures to prevent accidental edits

## Solution

This PR exposes the existing internal `EditorOption.readOnly` as a user-configurable setting by:

1. **Adding user-facing configuration**: Modified `editorOptions.ts` to include a description for the `readOnly` option, which automatically exposes it as `editor.readOnly` in VS Code settings
2. **Workbench integration**: Updated `textEditor.ts` to respect the global setting by combining it with existing per-file readonly logic using logical OR
3. **Comprehensive testing**: Added tests for both the basic option functionality and workbench integration

## Behavior

When `editor.readOnly` is enabled:
- All editors become read-only regardless of file-specific readonly status
- Editing operations (typing, paste, drag & drop, etc.) are blocked at the core editor level
- The `editorReadonly` context key is set, disabling editing commands and keybindings
- Per-file readonly functionality continues to work as before (logical OR behavior)

The setting combines with existing readonly mechanisms:
```
Final readonly state = Global editor.readOnly OR File-specific readonly
```

## Example Usage

Users can now enable the setting via:
- Settings UI: Search for "editor read only" 
- Settings JSON: `"editor.readOnly": true`
- Command Palette: "Preferences: Open Settings" → search "readonly"

## Implementation Details

- **Minimal changes**: Leverages existing readonly infrastructure
- **No breaking changes**: Maintains backward compatibility with all existing readonly functionality
- **Proper precedence**: Global setting takes effect when enabled, but doesn't override existing per-file readonly
- **Dynamic updates**: Configuration changes are applied immediately to open editors

The implementation builds on VS Code's existing robust readonly system, ensuring consistent behavior across all editor types and features.

title: Add proper User-Agent header for MCP server requests

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: chat-mcp-management
labels.description: Issues related to browsing and managing MCP Servers in VS Code

body:
## Summary
VS Code's MCP (Model Context Protocol) client currently sends requests with only `node` as the User-Agent header, making it impossible to distinguish VS Code MCP traffic from other Node.js applications in server logs and analytics.

## Problem Description
When VS Code makes requests to MCP servers, the User-Agent header currently shows only:
```
User-Agent: node
```

Suggested
```
User-Agent: VsCode/x.x.x (darwin arm64)
```

Benefits:
1. Server compatibility
2. Proper analytics and monitoring
3. Helps with debugging and client identification
4. Follows HTTP best practices

title: Track disposables per client in PolicyChannel to prevent resource leaks
body:
## Problem

The `PolicyChannel` class had a TODO comment indicating a need to track disposables per client. The current implementation used a single `DisposableStore` shared across all clients, which could cause resource management issues:

- When multiple clients connect to the policy service, their event listeners are stored in the same disposable store
- If one client disconnects, there's no way to dispose only that client's resources without affecting other clients
- This could lead to memory leaks or premature disposal of active listeners

## Solution

This PR implements per-client disposable tracking by:

1. **Replacing the single `disposables` field** with a `Map<unknown, DisposableStore>` that tracks disposables by client context
2. **Updating method signatures** to properly use the context parameter:
   - `listen(ctx: unknown, event: string)` - now uses the context to create/retrieve client-specific disposables
   - `call(ctx: unknown, command: string, arg?: any)` - updated for consistency with `IServerChannel` interface
3. **Adding `disposeClient(ctx: unknown)`** method to dispose resources for a specific client
4. **Enhancing the `dispose()`** method to clean up all client disposables

## Key Changes

### Core Implementation
- Each client context gets its own `DisposableStore` for isolated resource management
- Event listeners are registered using the client-specific disposable store
- Resources can be disposed per-client or globally

### Testing
Added comprehensive unit tests covering:
- Per-client disposable isolation
- Individual client resource cleanup
- Global disposal functionality
- Error handling for unknown events/commands

## Benefits

- **Prevents resource leaks**: Clients can be disposed independently without affecting others
- **Proper interface compliance**: Now correctly implements the `IServerChannel<TContext>` pattern
- **Memory efficiency**: Eliminates accumulation of stale event listeners
- **Backward compatibility**: Existing functionality remains unchanged

This follows the established VS Code pattern used in other IPC channels where resources are tracked per-context and disposed individually when clients disconnect.

title: npm run postinstall fails outside a Git repo

title: Create dino icon and use it in copilot menu instead of snake icon
body:
Creates a new dino icon and replaces the snake icon (🐍) with the dino icon in the copilot menu to provide a more dinosaur-like appearance as requested.

## Changes Made

This PR creates a completely new icon and updates the copilot menu implementation:

- **New dino icon**: Added `dino: register('dino', 'squirrel')` to `codiconsDerived` in `src/vs/base/common/codicons.ts`
  - The dino icon aliases to the existing squirrel glyph, which provides a more animal-like, dinosaur-adjacent appearance
  - Uses the existing squirrel glyph (0xeb58) to avoid requiring font file modifications

- **Updated copilot menu references**: Replaced `Codicon.snake` with `Codicon.dino` in `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/actions/chatActions.ts`:
  - CommandCenter menu item
  - TitleBar menu item  
  - CopilotTitleBarMenuRendering primary action icon

## What's Preserved

- All other chat sparkle usage remains unchanged (only copilot menu affected)
- Error and warning states still use appropriate `chatSparkleError` and `chatSparkleWarning` icons
- No functional changes to chat behavior or menu functionality

## Impact

- **Files changed**: 2 (`src/vs/base/common/codicons.ts` and `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/actions/chatActions.ts`)
- **Lines changed**: 4 (1 new icon definition + 3 icon references)
- **Risk**: Minimal - purely cosmetic icon change with no functional impact

The copilot menu will now display with a dino icon (represented by the squirrel glyph) instead of a snake, providing the requested dinosaur-like visual appearance while maintaining all existing functionality.

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT SUFFIX -->

Created from VS Code via the [GitHub Pull Request](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=GitHub.vscode-pull-request-github) extension.

title: TODO indentation is off
body: TODO indentation is off - too much to the right, feels alien with the rest of text / tool calls On a higher level - I am not convinced we should show TODOs in the middle of the response. Just showing it at the top is good enough for now. The longer term goal should be that Todos are higher level nodes that are expandable, so user can actually see what work was done for that particular todo. fyi @digitarald

title: View changes button in working set should be a toggle?
body: Right now we have a "Show all changes" button in the working set title, and a show changes button per element in the working set. Should these button be toggles? E.g. if the changes are shown and visible, clicking on Show all changes should show back the original file? I am not convinced about this proposal, but imho might make for a more natural interaction. E.g. similar how the editor title area has a show diff button, that toggles back to show editor once the diff is shown. Curious to hear your thoughts

body:
Testing #264098

This is a small UX discussion point. I saw the following pattern used on GitHub and in the Pull Requests extension where selecting an option from the dropdown permanently changes the button state by default. The option `Create on GitHub` could then be placed into the dropdown (the two would essentially swap). I am just wondering if this could be a good UX change. @mrleemurray

title: Copilot does not edit files

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
Hello everyone,

I am writing to see if this has happened to anyone else.

As of today, Copilot is not editing my files directly

After thinking about it and checking that it has not done so, it tries to do it through PowerShell.

I use Copilot Pro, and today my credits were renewed, so I don't know if that has anything to do with it.

I signed out of my account and signed back in, but it's still the same.

In addition, it's buggy because I can't open new chats (pressing '+' does nothing), nor does it let me switch between agent, ask, or edit mode.

Has this happened to anyone else?

Thanks

body:
Description:
The Remote - SSH extension fails to connect to any SSH/FTP server in VS Code versions above 1.85.2. It works fine in version 1.85.2.

Steps to Reproduce:

Install VS Code > 1.85.2

Install Remote - SSH extension

Try connecting to a remote server → fails

Expected: SSH/FTP connection succeeds
Actual: Connection fails

title: Support publishing repositories directly to organization accounts
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

### Feature Request

Currently, when using VS Code’s **Source Control (Git)** panel and the **“Publish to GitHub”** action, the repository is always published under the signed-in user’s personal GitHub account.

For teams that mainly work under **organization accounts**, this creates friction:

* We must first create a repository manually on the organization via the GitHub website.
* Then update the remote URL in VS Code (`git remote set-url origin …`).
* Only after that can we use VS Code’s Source Control UI normally.

### Suggested Improvement

Please add support for **publishing directly to a GitHub organization account** from the Source Control / GitHub extension UI.

Possible implementations:

1. When choosing “Publish to GitHub,” provide a dropdown to select between the user’s personal account and organizations they belong to.
2. Use the GitHub API to list organizations and allow the user to choose where to create the repository.

### Benefits

* Streamlined workflow for developers working in teams/organizations.
* Keeps all repository management inside VS Code.
* Matches expectations from users who already have sufficient permissions in an organization.
